answers.answer: Diabetes typically causes pain and numbness in the legs and hands in what is called a 'stocking/glove pattern'-- the areas effected are the areas covered by stockings and gloves.  The technical term is 'diabetic peripheral neuropathy';  it can feel like severe burning and is associated with numbess in the same areas as the pain.  The classic medication is an anticonvulsant to reduce the firing of damaged and irritated nerves--  Lyrica and gabapentin are probably used the most.  The goal is to slowly taper the dose up as high as the person can tolerate, up to a certain (high) limit.The hand symptoms MIGHT be related, or they may be from poor blood flow;  diabetes causes blockage of the small blood vessels over time, and this can lead to poor circulation to the hands and fingers.  Sometimes a medication that relaxes the blood vessels can help--  the classic medication would be a Calcium-channel blocker like nifedipine.
